longDescription: Tulsi (Sanskrit: ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ä, Ocimum tenuiflorum), also known as Holy Basil, is one of the most sacred plants in Hinduism. Revered as a manifestation of the goddess Lakshmi and deeply connected to Lord Vishnu, Tulsi is worshiped in Hindu households and temples across India. According to legend, Tulsi was originally the devoted wife Vrinda who was transformed into the plant. The Tulsi plant is considered so sacred that it is often planted in courtyards and special raised structures (Tulsi Vrindavan). Her leaves are essential in worship rituals dedicated to Vishnu and Krishna. Tulsi is believed to purify the surroundings, ward off evil spirits, and bring divine blessings. In Ayurveda, Tulsi is highly valued for its medicinal properties and is called 'The Queen of Herbs.'
shortDescription: Holy basil plant sacred to Vishnu, representing devotion and considered a manifestation of Lakshmi

mythologyContexts.usage: Tulsi is worshiped daily in Hindu homes, especially by Vaishnavites. Her leaves are offered to Vishnu and Krishna during puja and are placed on prasad (blessed food). The plant is considered a threshold between heaven and earth. Tulsi leaves are essential in rituals, and devotees circumambulate the plant while chanting prayers. The annual Tulsi Vivah ceremony celebrates the symbolic marriage of Tulsi to Vishnu or his avatars.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Tulsi represents supreme devotion (bhakti) to the divine. Her story as Vrinda demonstrates the transformation that occurs through pure devotion - even in apparent tragedy, divine grace prevails. The plant growing upward symbolizes spiritual aspiration, while her presence in the home represents the sanctification of domestic space. The requirement to care for Tulsi daily teaches discipline and devotion. Her leaves offered to Vishnu represent the offering of one's entire being to God.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Tulsi is present in virtually every Hindu home and temple dedicated to Vishnu. The plant is so sacred that it is considered a sin to uproot or harm her. Tulsi leaves are placed in the mouth of the dying to ensure liberation. A necklace made of Tulsi beads (Tulsi mala) is worn by Vaishnavites and used for chanting mantras. In traditional medicine (Ayurveda), Tulsi is revered as a healing plant with extensive therapeutic properties, bridging spiritual and physical well-being.
